newsitem.title: USA: High school student questioned in Levin slaying.
newsitem.headline: High school student questioned in Levin slaying.

text.p: A student at the high school where the murdered son of Time Warner Inc's top executive taught has been questioned about the slaying, media reports said Thursday.

Local radio and newspapers said police believed Jonathan Levin, 31, was murdered for his automatic teller machine card. Police sources said they thought he was jabbed with a steak knife until he revealed the personal identification number that gave access to the cash dispenser, the reports said.

Levin, a high-school English teacher and son of Time Warner chief executive and chairman Gerald Levin, was found Monday shot through the head in his one-bedroom Manhattan apartment. He had been bound and gagged and there was no sign of forced entry.

WCBS-AM radio and The New York Post said police had questioned one of Levin's former students at New York's Taft High School about the slaying. The student had left a message on Levin's telephone answering machine after the murder.
Taft is an inner city public high school in the poor South Bronx section of the city.

Detectives are checking the student's alibi. He allegedly has a criminal history, with two arrests for violent crimes, the reports said. A police spokeman said he could not comment on the report. There have been no arrests.

The Post and WCBS reported an ATM card was missing from Levin's wallet. Police investigators believe the killer shot Levin late Friday afternoon, raced to a Chase Manhattan Bank branch a few blocks away and withdrew $800.
Authorities are reviewing video tapes from the bank's security cameras to help identify a suspect.
Levin was buried Wednesday after an emotional funeral service that drew students from his inner-city school and some of the country's most powerful media executives.
